poem:
Taxation on Hold  

The line is long,  
a queue of voices,  
electronically tamed.  
A nation waits—  
patience on hold,  
each tick  
an echo of  
lost moments.  
In silent rooms,  
fingers drift  
to keys and screens.  
Words on papers—  
numbers click into place,  
while across lines,  
a country sighs.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Watchdog accuses HMRC of deliberately ‘degrading’ phone services Parliament’s spending watchdog has accused HM Revenue & Customs of deliberately running down its phone services to force people to go online after finding the average call waiting time has passed 23 minutes – almost double the figure of two years earlier. With people across the country working to finish their self-assessment return before the 31 January deadline, the public accounts committee (PAC) said it was “concerned". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
